metadata.title: Who is the Premier League’s Most Important Player? | by Callum Ballard | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Who is the Premier League’s Most Important Player?
metadata.description: The Premier League season is more than two-thirds done. Liverpool have the thing pretty much sewn up (see my earlier blog about how they’ve achieved such superiority), and the usual suspects are…

all_paragraphs: The Premier League season is more than two-thirds done. Liverpool have the thing pretty much sewn up (see my earlier blog about how they’ve achieved such superiority), and the usual suspects are involved in the annual scrap to avoid relegation.

In my ‘On Target’ blog series, I have been documenting my quest to ‘Moneyball’ Fantasy Premier League (FPL). So far, we’ve looked at getting data from the Premier League website using interactive web scrapers, and how to use object oriented programming to organise that data in a user-friendly way.

The ultimate aim of all this will be to create a model to predict which players are likeliest to score in upcoming games. Before getting to the nuts and bolts of neural networks, however, it is worth taking a step back and thinking about the rich dataset we’ve created. We have line-by-line data for every single shot taken in the Premier League so far — there’s a whole world of EDA we could dive into!

In FPL, there is an concept known as the ‘Talisman Theory’. Popularised by the FPL community ‘Who Got The Assist’ (WGTA), it broadly states that every team will have one individual ‘Talisman’ player who, for whatever reason, elevates the team’s performance. The Talisman player scores the team’s goals (or at least sets them up for other players), and their team’s play generally suffers in their absence.

How can we best identify such players? WGTA approaches this problem by examining the Fantasy points that players score. My approach is slightly different, in as much that I’ll think about raw match data, in particular shot and goal involvement.

Let’s start with something simple — which players have been involved in the most shots, and the most goals. By ‘involved’, we mean players who either took the shot, or those that ‘assisted’ the shot, i.e. made the final pass to the shooting player.

This suggests that Kevin De Bruyne of Manchester City has been the most instrumental player in terms of shot and goal involvement. We see from his relatively small bubble size that this is primarily due to ‘assists’ — De Bruyne tends not to score goals, but provide them for other players.

We can see this impact when we look at the best attacking partnerships. This considers the number of shots that players have assisted for each other over the course of the season so far — we see that De Bruyne features in three of the league’s top ten partnerships.

So we can probably conclude that De Bruyne is a ‘Talismanic’ player for Manchester City. Of course, this finding was made easy by the fact that Manchester City as a team score lots of goals (they had scored more than any other team in the league at time of writing). How could we think about the Talismans of teams who are less prolific?
A simple method could be to look at the percentage of a team’s shots and goals that a player was involved in.

De Bruyne is still towards the top right of the plot (which is where we’d expect an ‘important’ player to be). This time, however, we see that players of smaller teams are more prominent; Teemu Pukki of Norwich has scored over 60% of his team’s goals, and no player has been involved in a higher share of his team’s shots than Raul Jiminez of Wolves.

Share of shots and goals is a nice start, though we can get even more scientific. Let’s think of each team as its own ‘social network’. Then we can think of each player as a node within the network for their respective teams. The weight of the ‘edges’ between each pair of nodes can then be defined by the number of times that those two players have assisted each other’s shots.

Note — we can implement this using NetworkX, a nice little package for network analysis in Python. I’ll not go into too much detail on my exact code for this, since it involved a decent chunk of data preparation that’s awkward to explain out of context. However, the part that actually uses NetworkX is relatively straightforward. I recommend looking through their tutorial, which discusses graph creation, editing, and visualisation.
Let’s use Kevin De Bruyne’s Manchester City team as an example.

As expected, we see that De Bruyne is well connected in the network. We note the very ‘heavy’ edges, connecting him to players like Sergio Aguero, Raheem Sterling, and Riyad Mahrez. Recall that these three players had very productive partnerships with De Bruyne.
What about the two other players we highlighted in the ‘share of shots’ analysis?

Norwich City’s network is much less strongly connected compared to Manchester City’s (we would expect this — Manchester City have had 70% more shots than Norwich so far this season). We also see that Norwich are much more reliant on a core of players (namely Pukki, Buendia, and Cantwell).

The same is true for Wolves, to a degree, though Wolves have had slightly more shots than Norwich, and their wider team appears better connected, with at least five or six players that seem to assist each other’s shots relatively frequently.
Of course, just eyeballing a visualisation isn’t especially rigorous. Happily, network theory comes with several metrics that attempt to enumerate how ‘central’ a node is within a network.

We should ensure that any centrality metric we use considers the edge weights — a player who is assisting a teammate many times is more important to the team than a player who only assists them once. One measure that does this is ‘weighted betweenness’.

In a given network, betweenness quantifies the number of times a node acts as a bridge along the shortest path between two other nodes. In other words, to calculate Kevin De Bruyne’s ‘betweenness’, we calculate the shortest possible ‘journeys’ between every pair of players in the Manchester City network. We then calculate the share of those ‘journeys’ that pass through the De Bruyne node.

As mentioned, the betweenness metric can account for edge weights. In particular, we can say that the edge between two players who assist each other a lot is ‘shorter’ than other edges*. The shortest path between a given pair of nodes is, of course, likelier to use these short edges, therefore players with high goal involvement will feature on more of these shortest paths, and have higher levels of betweenness.

*For the purposes of these calculations, we can say that the length of the edge between two players is the inverse of (i.e. 1 divided by) the number of times that they assisted each other. The ‘shortest path’ between each node pair is then calculated using Dijkstra’s Algorithm.
So if we calculate the weighted betweenness of every player across the league, what do we find?

We see that the most important player for their team, by far, is Jack Grealish of Aston Villa. Indeed, if we visualise the Aston Villa network, we see Grealish slap bang in the middle, with very few strong edges between any other pair of players.
As expected, we see that there is a positive correlation between the share of a team’s shots a player has been involved in, and their ‘centrality’ within a team.
So who are the ‘Talisman’ players for each team?

Let’s look at the networks for the teams whose ‘Talisman’ have relatively low betweenness. As expected, these teams have quite an even spread of shot involvement, with no one player (or even any tight group of players) dominating.

This is the latest post in my blog series ‘On Target’, in which I’ll be attempting to build out a model for ‘Moneyballing’ Fantasy Premier League. I’d love to hear any comments about the blog, or any of the concepts that the piece touches on. Feel free to leave a message below, or reach out to me through LinkedIn.
